facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 709 of 1957 appealed by special leave from Madras High Court judgment dated April 18, 1955 in Case Referred No. 25 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Civil APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 709 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 18, 1955, of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 25 of 1952.

facts.text: Appellant is a firm acting as managing agents of Janardana Mills Ltd., Coimbatore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm acting as managing agents of the Janardana Mills Ltd., Coimbatore.

facts.text: Appellant purchased four contiguous plots of land admeasuring 5 acres 26 cents under four sale deeds on October 25, 1941, November 15, 1941, June 29, 1942, and November 19, 1942 for total Rs. 8,712-15-6.

anchor.surface_text: It purchased four companytiguous plots of land admeasuring 5 acres 26 cents under four sale deeds executed on October 25, 1941, November 15, 1941, June 29, 1942, and November 19, 1942, respectively for a total companysideration of Rs. 8,712-15-6.

facts.text: Properties sold by appellant in two lots to Janardana Mills Ltd. on September 1, 1947 and November 10, 1947 for total Rs. 52,600.

anchor.surface_text: After about five years these properties were sold by the appellant in two lots to the Janardana Mills Ltd. The first lot was sold on September 1, 1947, and the second on November 10, 1947, the total companysideration for the two sales being Rs. 52,600.

facts.text: Sales realized Rs. 43,887-0-6 in excess of purchase price for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: These two sales realised for the appellant a sum of Rs.43,887-0-6 in excess of the purchase price.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer treated Rs. 43,887 as income of appellant for assessment year 1948-49 and assessed to income-tax under business.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer treated the said amount of Rs. 43,887 as the income of the appellant for the assessment year 1948- 49, and assessed it to income-tax under the head business .

facts.text: ITO held no evidence that lands purchased for agricultural purposes or as investment, purchased solely to sell to mills at profit.

anchor.surface_text: The officer held that there was numberevidence to show that the appellant had purchased the said lands for agricultural purposes or that it had acquired them as an investment. He also found that, since the lands were adjacent to the Janar- dana Mills, the appellant must have purchased them solely with a view to sell them to the said mills with a profit.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner set aside ITO order, holding amount not assessable as not from profit-making scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate authority upheld the appellants companytention that the amount in question was number assessable as it cannot be hold to be income or profit resulting from a profit-making scheme, and set aside the order under appeal.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld ITO view, held amount gain from adventure in nature of business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the companyrectness of this order by taking an appeal against it to the Incometax Appellate Tribunal. The tribunal agreed with the view taken by the Income-tax Officer and held that the amount in question was number a capital accretion but a gain made in an adventure in the nature of business in carrying out a scheme of profit-making.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to Madras High Court: whether material for assessing Rs. 43,887 as income from adventure in nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant the tribunal then referred to the High Court of Madras the question suggested by it in these words whether there was material for the assessment of the sum of Rs. 43,887 being the difference between the purchase and sale price of the four plots of land as income from an adventure in the nature of trade .

facts.text: Madras High Court held transaction was adventure in nature of trade, justified taxing under business.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Rajagopalan and Rajagopala Ayyangar, JJ., and the question referred has been answered against the appellant. The High Court has held that the transaction in question was an adventure in the nature of trade and so the respondent was justified in taxing the amount in question under the head business for the relevant year.

facts.text: All four plots contiguous and adjoin the mills.

anchor.surface_text: All the plots which were thus purchased by the appellant piecemeal are companytiguous and they adjoin the mills.

facts.text: Plot purchased June 29, 1942 had house of six rooms fetching annual rent Rs. 100, net Rs. 80 after taxes.

anchor.surface_text: On the plot purchased on June 29, 1942, there stood a house of six rooms which fetched an annual rent of about Rs. 100 and after deduction of taxes, it left a net income of Rs. 80 per year to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant made no effort to put up structures or cultivate the plots while in possession.

anchor.surface_text: During the time that the appellant was in possession of these plots it made numbereffort to put up any structures on them or to cultivate them

facts.text: First purchase in name of Mr. G. Raja, assistant manager of Janardana Mills, son-in-law of partner, benami for appellant, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: The purchase of the first item of property by the appellant had been made in the name of Mr. G. Raja, assistant manager of the Janardana Mills Ltd., who is the son-in-law Of G. Venkataswami Naidu, one of the partners of the appellant firm. ... It is number disputed that the purchase in the name of V. G. Raja was benami for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended properties bought as investment, rejected by tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, urged by the appellant that the properties had been bought as an investment. This plea was rejected by the tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant contended purchased plots for building tenements for mill labourers, rejected by tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal likewise rejected the appellants case that it had purchased the plots for building tenements for the labourers working in the Janardana Mills.

facts.text: Appellant alternatively contended mills purchased due to industrial tribunal award in June 1947 recommending tenements.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively it was urged by the appellant that the Janardana Mills decided to purchase the plots because an award passed by an industrial tribunal in June 1947 had recommended that the mills should provide tenements for its labourers.

facts.text: Tribunal held appellant purchased plots solely with idea of selling at profit to mills, as managing agent could influence.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal was number impressed even by this plea and so it ultimately held that the plots had been purchased by the appellant wholly and solely, with the idea of selling them at profit to the mills. The tribunal thought that since the appellant was the managing agent of the mills it was in a position to influence the decision of the mills to purchase the properties from it

facts.text: Supreme Court held transaction is adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was right in taking the view that, on the facts and circumstances proved in this case, the transaction in question is an adventure in the nature of trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balanced multiple factors (series of contiguous purchases adjoining mills by managing agents, no cultivation/development/use beyond minimal rent, sold at profit after consolidation, sole intent to resell not rebutted by evidence, corroborated by position to influence buyer).
